newsitem.title: GERMANY: World book sales post record growth-survey.
newsitem.headline: World book sales post record growth-survey.

text.p: The global book market posted record growth of eight percent last year and China looks set to expand fastest of all by the year 2000, a survey showed on Thursday.

Market analysts Euromonitor, releasing the survey results at the world's biggest book fair in Frankfurt, said that in 1991-1995 world book sales rose by 24.3 percent from $64.3 billion to $80 billion.

"Interestingly the main reason for the strong value growth lies in the reported difficulties. Dramatically higher paper prices forced up the unit price of books, resulting in value sales increases," Euromonitor said.
The United States topped the retail sales market with $25.5 billion worth of sales in 1995 followed by Japan, Germany, Britain and France.
Euromonitor forecast: "By the year 2000 the Americas will continue to lead the world's book market with a projected value of $37 billion."
It said supermarkets now offered the greatest threat to traditional booksellers. "Their share of book retail sales remains low but it is rising across all markets worlwide," the survey said.
Jason Armitage, Euromonitor reports editor, said that the Chinese publishing market is set to enjoy staggering growth.
"China is forecast to post double the growth rate of any developed market by the turn of the next century at over 28 percent between 1996 and 2000."
He said the Asia-Pacific region had the fastest growth rate of any area in the past four years.
Electronic publishing could be equally spectacular.

"Provided government restrictions do not inhibit organic growth of Internet publishing, China presents a potentially massive market for electronic business publishing in particular which will benefit from rapidly rising PC ownership," he said.
